text: I am a person hey hey hey hey hi
everyone fat Tony that tan though here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
botanist record 6 flora botanist is a
one-man black metal project that is had
a number of albums released thus far if
we are to go by the Roman numerals on
this record you can assume that this is
the sixth installment of the ongoing
botanist musical saga and even though I
am reviewing this project just now I
have been conscious of it for a while
and while I can't say I have been a fan
of the bottom use ik I have found it
pretty interesting in that the approach
taken to black metal in this project is
kind of experimental it's lo-fi there is
also hammered dulcimer yes hammered
dulcimer which is a pretty strange
choice for a black metal record and on
previous botanist releases I thought it
was just a little gimmicky however on
this latest release we see the
incorporation of some bass guitar and
some harmonium and this hammered
dulcimer is typically just compressed
it's distorted it's just overblown to
the point where it sounds kind of like a
distorted guitar and now on this latest
release we are getting the inclusion of
some bass and some keyboards harmonium
specifically this record is botanist at
its most wonderful beautiful sounding
most detailed botanist has one foot in
the old harsh lo-fi world of black metal
and another foot in the grave new world
of black metal where the production and
the melodies typically are very bright
occasionally epic or uplifting the music
on this record sounds kind of like
sunrays or just a musical aurora
borealis or like beautiful colorful
exotic flowers which isn't too out of
comparison considering that every single
track on this record is named after a
plant now this LP is 10 tracks long it's
got an interlude at the end and again
despite being black metal the the sound
the tone of this record is pretty warm
and fuzzy you have those wretched yeah
vocals all over this record occasionally
you know some clean vocals some whispers
of course there are some really
aggressive drums on this thing blast
beats but despite all that this LP is
kind of inviting don't go into this
thing expecting that big polished
soaring sound that you would get on like
a deaf heaven record or a wolves and
throne room record bond this style is
much more raw visceral and direct and
the inclusion of hammer dulcimer just
like on previous releases continues to
give botanists a sound like no other
black metal project the sustain on the
dulcimer is amazing for the style of
music as well as the very metallic tone
of these notes the instrumentation a lot
of the time sounds gorgeous just as it
does on tracks like the opener stargazer
or Calais Steen on and even though the
melodies on this record can sound
beautiful things can take a turn for the
dark really quickly just like on the
tracks in a moment partha Ngoc salon
where the melody here is so devilish
that even the bright hammered dulcimer
can't distract away from how just evil
this lead is I wish the vocals were a
little louder sometimes though they do
sound quite harsh but they are mixed
very low it's kind of like having
somebody in a very scary way whisper to
you as you press your ear against this
wall of gorgeous sound the sound really
draws you in but the moment you get you
know really comfortable with it and you
feel immersed in it you sort of find
that there's this really just odd
shadowy figure walking through it which
for me was the case on the track teri
though fight where the melody on this
track is is very lullaby ish there are a
few songs where the sustain of the
hammered dulcimer may be brought
together with the harmonium makes for a
particularly droney soundscape very
relaxing very gorgeous there are a few
tracks here and there where you get a
little bit of odd time signatures stuff
and the song just before the closer is
one of the most aggressive propulsive
hard-hitting songs on the entire LP this
this record really ends off with a bang
I think compositionally this record has
quite a bit
of variety to it even if the very rough
and lo-fi production leaves a lot of
these songs feeling a little Sammy Sammy
but even if all these tracks have a
similarly hazy and fuzzy feel to them
it's really the compositions underneath
that that just attract me there are
maybe two or three songs on this thing
where I feel like maybe melodically
these tracks are a little too basic I
wish that the harmonium came in and did
a little bit more or the bass or that I
just wasn't getting some basic hammered
dulcimer chords specifically on tracks
like dianthus but still I came away from
this album loving it I think this is
botanist most complex and interesting
album yet and I look forward to seeing
this musical project progress into the
future I'm feeling a light decent eight
on this thing transition if you've given
this record to listen what did you think
did you love it did you hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
that's it
Anthony Fantana botanist music forever
